title: Martin Parr webchat â as it happened | Art and design | The Guardian
summary: i 'm a big `` in '' person â i love being part of europe .
film or digital ? there 's no looking back .
it 's true : i am obsessed with soviet space dogs . i have a soft spot for laika .
many people accuse me of being cruel and exploitative ¦ but i 'm not interested in doing a pr exercise .
i take as many bad photos as anyone else .
my most memorable portrait was taken in pyongyang in the 1990s . everyone is in north korea these days , but it used to be novel .

documents.title: that 's all for today
text: thanks to everyone who took part .
martin says : now i am going for a cup of tea .
so thank you for your questions .
martin parr 's selfie at the guardian offices in london
raja indra putra asks : you seem to have several project going on at the same time .
what are your current long-term projects ?

guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:58pm i will be doing a book about the uk - i 've taken a lot of in the last ten years and i 'm working towards a big statement about my relationship to great britain .
but now i am going for a cup of tea .
so thank you for your questions .
slimpanatella asks : which project do you consider your best work ?
and which do you consider your weakest ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:56pm i 'd still say the last resort is my best project but i always hope the next one will be equally as memorable .
the truth is , that probably ai n't going to happen .
myrtle1 asks : if you had to save one photo book in your collection , which would it be ?

guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:55pm i would still take robert franks ' the americans - it 's the first photo book i bought in 1972 in a bookshop in manchester and as a compendium of images it 's almost impossible to beat .
ruudawakening asks : what do all great photographs have in common ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:55pm hi ruudawakening the only commonality is that i took them all !
icommentthereforeiam asks : street photography seems now to be considered a genre in itself .
do you think there 's any sense in this ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:54pm i 'd say street photography has been street photography for many years .
get out there while you can because sooner or later i 'm sure the authorities will stop the ability for you take any photo and do what you like with it .
to publish and show it without any recourse .
as is the case in many other european countries .
such as france and germany .

documents.title: i 'm a big `` in '' person â i love being part of europe
text: liam cleary asks : eu : in or out ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:52pm i 'm a big in person - anti-brexit .
i love being part of europe and travelling and showing and working there .
goneforaburton asks : bradford or london ?

guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:48pm i was very happy to sign the guardian and times letter when the issue of moving the photographic collection from bradford to london was quite rightly aired and criticised .
hopefully now with the huge response that has been generated , they may reconsider the whole position of the national media museum .
katiemongoose asks : what do you think is the difference between seeing an exhibition and reading the exhibition catalogue ?
which do you prefer ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:46pm despite my great love of photo books , there 's nothing quite like seeing a good exhibition when it 's well hung with a strong narrative .
and although the catalogue will act as a souvenir it does n't have the same impact as seeing the show .

documents.title: it 's true : i am obsessed with soviet space dogs . i have a soft spot for laika
text: katiemongoose asks : i heard you collect soviet space dog memorabilia .
what 's your favourite item , and which is your favourite dog ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:45pm yes , indeed .
i am obsessed with spacedog ephemera .
and the three dogs you see most of all are laika , belka and strelka .
but i have a soft spot for leica because the poor dog perished and yet still became a national hero in the space race against america .
the others came back down !
did you know that the spacedogs were all stray dogs found in the streets of moscow because they were thought to be more independent and streetwise .
this would apply well to a space capsule - they could also be trained easier .

documents.title: film or digital ? there 's no looking back
text: waltjabsco asks : someone will ask so i may as well : film or digital ?

guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:42pm i was n't the quickest to change form film to digital - i did so in around 2008 when digital cameras made a huge leap forward with the introduction of the full-frame dslr and now there 's no looking back because the quality is so good .
also i can not now say that i miss a good photo because i was changing film as now the chip will have space for 500 images .
ian healy asks : do you want your work to be considered documentary , or more in the realm of conceptual visual arts ?
i mean more like what might be considered art guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:39pm hi ian .
so at heart i have a documentary responsibility to fulfil , but occasionally you can get a photograph that almost transcends that and becomes a memorable image in its own right .
silly billy asks : how have you gotten away with it ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:37pm gotten away with what ?

swordofjustice asks : do you think a time will come when the uk will show the same respect for photography and our great photographers that has long been shown in , say , france , germany and the us ?
to me it seems that so many galleries barely pay even token service in this country to the works of some of our greats .

guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:36pm hi swordofjustice , this is a very good question and you 've touched on what i think is an important point i think things are improving here in the uk , especially now that the tate has started to embrace photography .
but it 's still very difficult to get photography reviewed with the same ease that is in the say a country like france .
adrian searle , for example , has never reviewed a show of mine in the uk .
and the guardian are meant to embrace photography !
dogsart68 asks : how much does depth of field matter to you ?
i love using low f-stops , the lower the better .
your work is always so vibrantly coloured .
how do you achieve this ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:34pm i do n't really consider fstops that much .

but when i use my macro lens with a ringflash , it 's usually in the range of f5.6 the colour palette was originally thought about with a combination of flash and colour negative film and with the introduction of digital the colours are now less saturated and i 'm quite happy about that .
topographicalerror asks : first of all congrats on the rhubarb triangle series really evocative of the labour that goes into producing the stuff .
do you think the non-conformists series would 've worked as well in colour as they do in black and white ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:33pm the non-conformists was done at a time when serious photography was always done in black and white .
colour did n't really take off in the uk until the 80s .
so i am happy they were done in black and white and can not imagine this series being in colour .

documents.title: many people accuse me of being cruel and exploitative ¦ but i 'm not interested in doing a pr exercise .
text: coffeebody asks : what do you make of stuart freedman 's criticism that some of [ parr 's work ] can come across sometimes as rather cruel ?
is that fair ?
do you feel cruel in the work that you do ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:32pm many people accuse me of being cruel and exploitative .
i do n't see it like that .
i get on with people and enjoy their company but i 'm not interested in doing a pr exercise .
i 'm trying to show the world as i find it .
so often there is a sense of mischief in that work which other people can see in a different light .
irapho asks : in the sooke interview , you also said : whether i take a great ' photo is down to luck .
the rhubarb triangle is a great oddball english story .
however , the images are comparatively weak , despite the 100-1 shoot ratio .
was this because luck was n't with you , or simply that your technique appears to have been absent on this occasion ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:31pm i 'm not particularly engaging with my critics , i 'm just telling the truth as i find it .
sixtyfive asks : the editor colin jacobson once called you a gratuitously cruel social critic who has made a large amount of money by sneering at the foibles and pretensions of other people .
bearing this in mind , in a recent interview with alastair sooke , you said , most of the i take are not very good .
for the hubarb commission , i took 3,000-4,000 and ended up with 40 .
if i knew how to take a great photo , i would stop .
is this a defence designed to disarm or enrage your many critics ?
do you consider yourself the quintessential photographer of everyday britain , given your somewhat scattergun and peculiar approach ?
you began your career with the non-conformists .
have you considered any other religious bodies worthy of your attention ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:30pm come in sixtyfive .
i remember well the colin jacobson comment and had realised quite early on in my career that being controversial did me no harm .
on the rhubarb commission , i did take many photos and most of them were rejected because in any serious commission you have to take a lot of bad photographs .
you have to have failures to get across the idea of the project .
on the religious question , i looked at a lot of different religions in my recent work on the black country which has just been published by black country stories .
simonegiovetti asks : i need to know what to do to have any chance to win a photo competition , apart from making a great photo ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:25pm hi simone - sorry there is only one way to win a competition and that is with a memorable photo .
fedina grã¼nerlã¸kka asks : will you marry me ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:24pm hi fedina , nice thought but i 'm married already so i will have to decline .
mountaingirl2011 asks : what is your favourite publication of your own work ?
i really like the non-conformists .
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:24pm when i arrive at the pearly gates and they say get a couple of books out mate , i would put forward last resort and common sense .
jmoretonni asks : what are your thoughts about using social media to raise an art photographer 's profile ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:23pm hi jm !
i 'm all for social media in photography it 's one way of finding an audience for your work if you are really good .
in the last three months , i 've started my instagram thread .
and i 'm about to close down my flickr page because instagram has taken over .
my facebook page was started by someone who works at the who in geneva and she did it without asking me but now we supply her with information .
why not ?
smileyman asks : do you think henri cartier-bresson would have taken back his comment about your work being from another planet if he was still alive and saw the breadth of your interests ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:21pm hi smileyman !
the whole henry carton bresson episode was very exciting for me and i realised this incident would have a lasting impact i still keep a copy of his original fax with this accusation .
what was a slight form of criticism almost a celebration .
skeptical sam asks : what is next for martin parr ?

guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:19pm after this week with all the events surrounding the strange and familiar opening at the barbican , i 'm looking forward to going to cheltenham for the gold cup with my camera .
i 've only been once before .
am i photographing the horses of the people ?
the people of course !
fancy having to ask

documents.title: i take as many bad photos as anyone else
text: des byrne asks : in 2003 , you took a series of shots called the heatwave , in kilkee , ireland , which i do n't consider your greatest body of work .
are you happy with this series ?
your other work in ireland is great imho .
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:17pm hi des , i confess the kilkee are not that great but it was the only time i 've been in ireland when there was heatwave .
and you 'll note i 've never tried to exhibit these photos they are just part of the archive .
i have to confess many of the projects i do do not succeed i 'm only human .
i take as many bad photos as anyone else .

documents.title: my most memorable portrait was taken in pyongyang in the 1990s . everyone is in north korea these days , but it used to be novel
text: catherineriviera asks : which of the portraits taken of you around the world over the years reveals the most about you and the country in which it was taken ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:15pm hi catherine .
the most memorable portrait i have was taken in pyongyang on assignment for the guardian ! !
in the 90s .

it 's a hand coloured black and white photograph and it took six months to receive because the tour guide has to bring back photographic paper on his next trip - they 'd run out of it in the country .
so it took six months to receive it .
everyone is in north korea these days ; it 's no great novelty in those days it was .

andy carson asks : with stupidly high iso levels on digital cameras , do you think it 's about time companies listened to photographers and try to produce cameras with lower native iso levels than 100 or 200 and get rid of all the farty video features photographers do n't want or need ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:12pm i take your point but if you want a lower iso that 's always available so why do n't you stick to that .
likewise with what you call `` farty video features '' .
get one with without them or less of them , i do n't think you can avoid them these days !
movilla asks : what would you advise people are , effectively , copying your style to do ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:10pm hi movilla .
i would say carry on copying it because it 's the right thing to do to learn from all the other people who 've gone before us in photography sooner or later your own vision and language will emerge .
i 've learned from the likes of tonyray jones and garry winogrand for example .

documents.title: do i chat to the people i shoot ? of course , you 're going to have the occasional confrontation
text: hanfrancisco asks : how do you manage to get such intimate photographs with strangers , especially at the beach ?
do you ever talk to the subjects ?
do they ever confront you ?
i would love to walk across a beach taking candids of the people with a flash , but envisage a nasty public fight scene if i did so , or a benny hill-style chase at best .
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:08pm sometimes i engage with people when i shoot a project and very often i do not .
of course you are going to have the occasional confrontation , it 's an occupational hazard .
but most people i think are flattered to be photographed and to have the attention brought to them .
if there is one person in 50 who objects to being photographed they usually make this pretty evident .
thomas perring asks : there 's been recent questioning of digital storage of modern captured images : such images captured now may not be able to be viewed with future technology .
how do you feel about this and its potential effect for the future of photographers and photography ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:06pm so hi thomas .
i still would think of my books as the best legacy because they will never fade .
but i do back up my in many forms and many times to ensure they are digitally preserved .
i do have a team of people who do it for me though !
goneforaburton asks : robinson or emerson ?
stieglitz or steichen ?
adams or mortensen ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:05pm emerson , stieglitz and adams .
rebekka3000 asks : how important is the social class of the authorship of art and , in particular , photography ?
you once described yourself as caricaturally english and middle class , which many have found problematic in your documentation of working-class britain .
but does the artist 's background even matter when judging the piece ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:04pm hi rebekkah .
i am so middle class it 's ridiculous but over my career i 've photographed all classes because i 'm interested in de them all .
an artist 's background should not influence the take that anyone has .
lewisdenson asks : how important is it to make art that is accessible to everyone ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:01pm hi lewis , photography is the most democratic art form in the world , so accessibility is key to its success .
nick nicholas asks : every photo i take copies either your style or william eggleston 's .
any advice on how to find my own style ?

guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 1:00pm hi nick , when you find the subject that really excites you and and it brings out your passion and ability to connect , you will find your own style .
charlottebruning asks : it seems everywhere one post photos , whether social media or in a competition , the [ organisation ] seems to retain royalties and a lot of other rights .
how much of a problem do you think this is ?
guardian contributor martinparr1 14 march 2016 12:59pm hi charlotte , the internet is so vast , it 's unavoidable that are published without any royalties .
and i do n't mind this at all .
you should welcome people using your think of it as flattery and interest .

documents.title: martin is with us now
text: he says : here i 'm in the guardian office , ready for the most difficult questions possible !

documents.title: post your questions for martin parr
text: saturated in colour and humour , martin parr 's photos are instantly recognisable .
they show everyday life as banal , but also funny and a little surreal .

parr is most famous for his shots of tourists lapping up suncream and ice cream at the seaside , but he started out with a quieter black-and-white style , observing religious life in hebden bridge during the 1970s .
he 's an avid collector of photo books , and his extensive collection of postcards was exhibited at the barbican last year .
parr is returning to the gallery as curator of strange and familiar , an exhibition of non-british photographers ' images of britain .
his own photos of the city of london are currently on show at the guildhall art gallery .
with the barbican exhibition opening on 16 march , martin joins us on 14 march to answer your questions about his career in a live webchat at 1pm gmt .
post yours in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The quintessential photographer of everyday Britain answered your questions catch up on his views about a Brexit, which Soviet space dog is his favourite, what he thinks of people who call him cruel' and more.
